description: Erection of two storeys above existing building to form additional office/storage space and erection of detached two storey building for storage
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts, external lighting or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Consultations4no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No comments received.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for alterations to ground floor fenestrations to include replacement of rear openings with folding/sliding door and alterations to side window. Planning History09/12203/HOU - Erection of roof extension including raising height of roof by 1.3 metres to facilitate loft conversion. Granted planning permission, dated 04.06.2009.02/03111/FUL - Erection of roof extension (raising height of roof) with side dormer window to facilitate loft conversion. Refused planning permission, dated 28.05.2002.Site and SurroundingsThe site comprises a detached two-storey residential property on the southern side of Richmond Park Road. The site does not fall within a Conservation Area, nor is the building statutory or locally listed.  Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; and -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Accordingly, the Core Strategy states the Council's intention to protect the primarily suburban character of the Borough, its existing buildings and areas of high quality and historic interest from inappropriate development. The Council will seek opportunities for sensitive enhancement in these areas and in areas of poorer environmental quality, where character has been eroded or needs improving. The assessment of development proposals will be guided by the Borough Character Study and the Residential Design SPD, ensuring that new development:-	Recognises distinctive local features and character-	Has regard to the historic and natural environment-	Helps enhance locally distinctive places of high architectural and urban design quality-	Accords with neighbourhood "strategies for delivery" set out under "Character, Design and Heritage"-	Relates well and connects to its surroundingsThe proposals comprise the alteration of the rear ground floor fenestration to the property to glazed folding/sliding doors.The design of the glazing would be complementary to the existing fenestration and befitting of the overall design of the dwellinghouse, and is similar to other rear ground floor fenestration detailing.The proposals are assessed as generally in accordance with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames LDF Core Strategy (Adopted April 2012). Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The full length glazed folding/sliding doors would be situated to the rear of the existing dwellinghouse. These would not afford any direct views or opportunities for overlooking to neighbouring properties.  The proposed one side-facing window at ground floor would face onto the flank wall of the neighbouring property, and would merely replace the existing side window with a slightly larger updated window.The proposed windows are not considered to pose impacts on neighbouring amenity.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012).Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED.

Condition 4 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 22/03938/FUL  states: Prior to any above ground works (excluding demolition)  a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details: 1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point; 2) Appropriate fire alarm systems; 3) Passive and active fire safety measures; 4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread; 5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained. Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.Officer response: The submitted Reasonable Exception Statement is considered to be sufficient. As such, details submitted in relation to Condition 4 (Fire Safety Strategy) are hereby approved.

---Officer Report---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2022 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a terraced dwelling. It is noted that site levels vary between properties on the south side of Tankerton Road and that site levels fall away from the main dwellinghouse towards the rear end of the garden.It is noted that Nos. 36, 40 and 42 Tankerton Road are all identified as being at low-medium risk of surface water flooding.ProposalErection of single storey rear extension with terraceConsultation7 neighbours were notified of the application. 1 letter of objection has been received raising the following concerns:- Insufficient details of surface water drainage;- Increased surface water flood risk on-site and to neighbouring properties;- Ground levels at No. 42 are approximately 0.15m - 0.3m lower than the application site;- Loss of privacy from the patio;- Height of boundary fence/privacy screens;- Loss of daylight;- Spread of Mares tailOfficer Note: Mares tail is not a listed plant under a relevant Act (such as The Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 or the Environmental Protection Act 1990) so as to be relevant for planning purposes.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and buildings;- Flood RiskDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is noted that Nos. 40 and 36 are separated by an alleyway. The separation distance between the properties is considered sufficient to ensure no significant adverse impact in terms of loss of daylight/sunlight, overbearing impact, undue sense of enclosure or loss of privacy.Regarding adjoining No. 42, as is noted above, the application site appears to be set at a higher ground level than No. 42. Taken separately, the proposed single storey rear extension would not result in any significant adverse impact to the amenities of No. 42. However, in order to mitigate the loss of privacy resulting from the proposed raised terrace, boundary treatment/privacy screens of at least 1.8m (when measured from the upper surface of the terrace) would be required. On the basis of the available evidence and submitted information, a solid mass of approximately 7.5m in depth at a height of approximately 2.5m in height (as viewed from No. 42) would be erected along the boundary with No. 42. It is considered that the necessary boundary treatment/privacy screens and extension would, cumulatively, result in an unacceptable overbearing impact and an undue sense of enclosure to No. 42.Flood RiskParagraph 167 of the NPPF (2021) states that: 'When determining any planning applications, local planning authorities should ensure that flood risk is not increased elsewhere.'Policy DM4 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) sets out that the Council will require development to be designed to take into account flood risk from fluvial and surface water flooding and that development proposals will be considered in accordance with national guidance and the Borough Strategic Flood Risk Assessment (SFRA). Policy SI 13 of the London Plan seeks echoes the above requirements. It is noted that Nos. 36, 40 and 42 Tankerton Road are all identified as being at low-medium risk of surface water flooding. As is noted above, the proposed terrace is shown on the Proposed Floor and Roof Plans as being 3m in depth, whereas the proposed section drawings show it as approximately 4.5m in depth at a height of approximately 0.5m. Based on the Section drawings, the proposed terrace would be approximately 25.2sqm in area. No details of drainage arrangements for the proposed extension or terrace have been submitted.While there is an existing patio area at the application site, it is considered that the proposed extension and raised terrace would result in an increase in the amount of impermeable surfaces on site. As a result of this, surface water discharge/flow rates from the site could increase. Given the scale and nature of the proposed development, that the site and neighbouring properties are identified as being a low-medium risk of surface water flooding, and that no details of the proposed drainage arrangements have been submitted, Officers consider that insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that the proposed development would not increase flood risk on site or elsewhere.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
